Tang Dynasty, Hangzhou, Great Compassion Mountain, Chuan Zhong of the Tang Dynasty, Hangzhou, Great Compassion Mountain, Chuan Zhong of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Chuan Zhong, whose surname was Lu, was from Puzhou, Hedong.

He was born with extraordinary spiritual qualities and a unique physical appearance. His body was tall and straight, with a round and prominent skull, his voice sounded like a bell, and his complexion was like solidified fat.
His learning encompassed the entire ancient canon, and his literary style was rich and elegant.
At the age of twenty-five, he followed the plan and passed the jinshi examination, but he was not yet satisfied and thought of winning again.
Soon after, he suffered the grief of his mother's death, so he built a hut by her grave.
After completing the mourning period, he went straight to Beijing and became a monk at Tongzi Temple.
In less than two years, he had read all the scriptures.
The following year, he went to Mount Song to receive full ordination and studied the Vinaya.
In this way, he became well-versed in it. Suddenly, he admired the supreme vehicle and went to Mount Baizhang, where he deeply understood the profound meaning.
Later, he secluded himself at Changle Temple on Mount Heng, building a thatched hut on the mountain peak.
The Chief Minister of State Affairs, Cui Gong, deeply respected his conduct and thus built a separate hut for him.
The sun set in the evening, and he had only one meal for the whole day.
However, he lacked water and had to go far to fetch it with a worn-out jar.
Suddenly, in the deep night, a tiger howled and howled beside his hut. When he got up the next morning and looked, there was indeed a spring gushing forth, enough for his use.
Later, he went to Hangzhou. There was a mountain north of the Qiantang River called Dacizhong.
Before long, donors and believers came from afar.
In turn, they built a large temple, and monks from all directions came to pay homage like clouds.
During the reign of Emperor Wuzong, who abolished Buddhism, he wore a short robe and was invited to live in the Dai family villa.
In the Renchen year of the Dazhong era, Prefect Liu first ordered him to shave his head, greatly reviving the Chan forest.
On the fifteenth day of the second month in the Renwu year, he entrusted [his teachings] and passed away.
At that time, the weather was gradually becoming hot, but his body showed no change, and his forehead was warm and moist.
In winter, he was buried in the stupa, living to the age of eighty-three, and having been a monk for fifty-four years.
Some say:
The mountain spring at Changle Temple suddenly dried up on the day of Zhonggong's death.
How strange!
It was only used by those in need.

The Biography of Shi Huanpu of Shaoshan in Luoyang of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Huanpu, was from an unknown place.
He inherited a pure and refined body, and his nature was humble and sincere.
He lived in a remote and humble place, but his requests for teachings were vast and his understanding was difficult to fathom.
After receiving full ordination, he studied the sutras and treatises.

He then traveled south to Liyang with his staff, met Jiashan, and found a connection in their minds. When a student came to ask about the teachings, he would take them by the hand and lead them back, not letting a single opportunity pass without guiding them.
For those he did not recommend, he encouraged them to read the sutras and Dharma, which was also close to the remaining style of Xiu and Ji.
Tang Dynasty, Hengshan, Angtou Peak, Biography of Rixiao Tang Dynasty, Hengshan, Angtou Peak, Biography of Rixiao Shi Rixiao, whose surname was Liu, was from Qixia.

His family was wealthy and powerful, and he received education from a young age. He extensively read the classics and also had a natural affinity for the teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi. He thought of becoming a monk.
He went to Damingsi Temple in Chang'an to study under Dharma Master Tanguang, received ordination, and transmitted the sutras and Dharma, becoming proficient in all of them.
He then traveled to Mount Song and asked for the essential instructions of Yuan Tong, and joyfully followed him.
Later, he traveled to Mount Heng and climbed the peak called Raising the Head, which was straight and lush with greenery, and he had the intention to stay there for the rest of his life.
He lived in a hut for twenty years. During the Huichang era of Emperor Wuzong, when Buddhism was persecuted, Zhao deeply entered a cave, ate chestnuts, drank water, and continued to breathe.
In the Dazhong era of Emperor Xuanzong, when Buddhism was revived, he led more than sixty disciples back to the old site of Mount Raising the Head, thatched a roof, and built a dwelling.
He lived there for another fifteen years, and his students gathered like waves.
In the Xian Tong era, he passed away at the age of 108.
On the third day of the second month in the third year, he was placed in a stupa, and a stele was erected to commemorate him.
People in the world called his Chan studies Raising the Head Zhao.
The Biography of Shi Xuanjian of Deshan Monastery in Langzhou, Tang Dynasty. Shi Xuanjian, whose surname was Zhou, was from Jiannan.
Born in a family with bad smells, he was young and intelligent, with an unusual temperament from past lives, and a sincere wish to leave the dust.
A great dragon does not bend in a small courtyard, a majestic osprey must soar in the layered sky. Having removed adornments, he should join the monastic order.
Following his ordination, he delved into the Vinaya Piá¹­aka. He thoroughly studied and mastered its various natures and characteristics.

Hearing that Chan teachings were flourishing in the area of Chonghu, he set his mind on wandering and visited Chan Master Longtan Chongxin, who was the second generation successor of Chan Master Shitou.
At first, he lived alone in a room, serving as an attendant for Longtan.
One night, Longtan held up a branch of fire and gave it to Guan. Guan took it and walked a few steps, saying:
I have long heard of Longtan, but upon arrival, neither the dragon nor the pool are seen.
Longtan said:
You have come close, my son.
In accord with the teachings, he became even closer to Longtan's room for more than thirty years.
Later, he stayed in Lizhou.
He stayed there for some time, but then Emperor Wuzong launched a persecution of Buddhism.
After Emperor Xizong returned to the capital and restored the Buddhist rites,

in the beginning of the Xiantong era, the Prefect of Wuling, Xue Yanwang, strongly invited him to stay at Deshan. His teachings spread far and wide, and Chan practitioners from all over the four seas gathered there.
In the winter and summer, there were always five hundred people in the hall.
His teachings were as vast as the ocean, difficult to fathom.
Xuefeng saw him and deeply appreciated him.
In the sixth year of the Xiantong era, the second year of the jiaxu cycle, on the third day of the twelfth month, he suddenly told his disciples:
Chasing after echoes by groping in the void, exhausting your spirit,
When you wake up from the dream, you realize it is not real, what else is there to do?
After saying this, he sat peacefully and passed away. He was eighty-four years old, and had been a monk for sixty-five years.
His body sat upright on the bed for seven days, as if he were still alive.
Those who speak of Chan teachings that are as sharp as an arrow have the style of Deshan's gate.
Now, the Dharma grandchildren in Xiang, Deng, and the east of Han are extremely prosperous.

Biography of Chan Master Zang Huan of Qixin Temple in Mingzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Chan Master Zang Huan of Qixin Temple in Mingzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Zang Huan, with the secular surname Zhu, was a person from Huating, Suzhou.
Before his mother conceived him and after his birth, they often smelled strange fragrances.
When he was a child, he once fell into a well, and a spirit lifted him out.
At the age of 10, he left home and took Dao Kuang as his teacher.
At the age of 20, he went to Mount Song to receive full ordination.
His mother often missed him and wept, so one of her eyes could not see. When he returned to visit, it immediately became clear.
After his mother's death, he mourned in grief and stayed by her grave. There were quite a few auspicious signs. His filial piety moved people, and because of this, he became famous.
He then traveled around to visit and seek the Way. He went to Mount Wufeng and met Chan Master Lingmo.
With a single word, they analyzed and their insights matched. The Way of revealing and concealing is what the sun and moon naturally do.
During the Huichang and Dazhong periods, the temple declined but was restored to prosperity.
Only Huan resided there, unaffected by the flickering flames, the burning heat, or the drowning waters.
Later, the Changshou Temple was rebuilt in Zhou and Luoyang, and he was ordered to reside there.
At that time, the Buddhist canon was burned and destroyed, with the scriptures reduced to ashes. He collected the scattered fragments and compiled them into the great canon.
Soon, Yang Gong of the South Sea took charge of Suzhou and invited Huan to return to the old forest to build a monastery.
In the twelfth year of the Dazhong era, the Suzhou patron Ren Jingqiu donated his residence to establish an institute and invited Huan to reside there.
The bandit leader Qiu Fu of Shan led two thousand troops to attack by day. Huan sat in meditation with closed eyes, his expression undisturbed.
The bandits were all terrified and kowtowed to apologize.
After the banditry was quelled, the prefecture petitioned to change the name to Qixin Temple to honor Huan's virtue.
Whenever he moved or stopped, Chan practitioners would gather, surrounding the hall and crowding the steps, like a gathering of clouds.
His learning flowed like a spring, and his guidance branched out in different directions.

The multitude who questioned and dispelled doubts, and the scholars who attacked the solid and sought the hidden, all stood up, dispelling the bitter mist, sitting and melting the solid ice, with a single word entering the spirit, forever breaking through deep delusions.

On the third day of the eighth month in the autumn of the seventh year of the Xian Tong era, he showed signs of illness and passed away, living to the age of seventy-seven and being a monk for fifty-seven years.
He ordered perfumed water to be used to shave his head and told his disciples:
I will be gone in seven days.
When the time came, he passed away.
His disciples grieved and temporarily buried him on Tian Tong Cliff.
Three years had passed, and one day an unusual fragrance lingered in the air, permeating far and near.
The disciples said to each other:
In the past, the master entrusted us to cremate his body three years later. Now, with this unusual fragrance,
they opened the stupa and saw that he was as if alive.

Huant said to the assembly at Changshou Temple in Luoyang:
In the past, I was the monk Tancui on Mount Siming. There is a tomb and stupa there.
The distance was far, and people doubted it. When they investigated the facts, they were all as he had said.
When Ren Sheng was about to welcome Huant, some people objected.
He replied:
When the house was first built, a strange monk told me to enlarge the gate. After twenty years, a sage would live here.
When Huant arrived, it was indeed twenty years.
Moreover, when Huan was about to leave Gusu, the assembly of disciples held him back. He then gave them a palm-leaf whisk, saying:
I am here, what doubts do you have?

The Biography of Zongjian of Guang'ai Temple in Luoyang, Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Zongjian of Guang'ai Temple in Luoyang, Tang Dynasty. The monk Zongjian, whose surname was Zhang, was originally from Nanyang, but moved to Guangling and was born in Huaibei.
He had a straightforward nature and a lofty demeanor. In the neighborhood, he was feared and respected by the people.
He met a physiognomist who said:
You are eight feet tall, with prominent eyebrows and bright eyes. In the future, you will surely receive honor and support.
Zongjian said:ğŸ”½I am not interested in fame and fortune.

Before the age of forty, he suddenly deeply believed in the Buddhist principles, and thus abandoned his wife and children, seeking ordination from a monk.
As soon as he entered the stage of precepts, he mostly guarded the mind-pearl, and thus realized Chan Na and suddenly understood the profound principles.
For several decades, those who liked it came from afar to ask questions.
Jian one by one pointed out, causing them to awaken.
He then traveled to Guang'ai Temple in Luoyang and hung his robe there.
At that time, Chan guests gathered like filial children serving their parents.
In Luoyang, when inviting Jian to set out food, he would always arrange a seat opposite Venerable Pindola, and the respect and reverence he received from people were all of this kind.

In the fifth year of the Huichang era, an edict was issued to abolish Buddhist temples and pagodas, and to have monks return to secular life, also following the example of purification and elimination.
He then wore a crow-feather hat and hempen clothes, and hid in the Hot Springs Villa of the imperial clan.
Later, on the hilltop, the tall trees were luxuriant, and the huge rocks were smooth. In the summer, Jian often entered meditation here, or attended to his felt duties.
Suddenly, he encountered torrential rain clouds, lightning striking the rocks, and violent winds approaching. Everyone here was frightened and terrified.
Jian only sat in meditation with joy, as if he did not hear anything.
Someone asked Jian, saying:
What kind of evil beast is this!
In the beginning of the Daming era, the imperial edict was proclaimed to revive Buddhism. Jian returned to his old residence in Luoyang.
His son one day came to visit from Guangling. He happened to meet Jian at the gate of the temple. The majestic appearance was solemn, and he could not be recognized anymore.
He then asked:
Where does the great virtuous Jian reside?
Jian pointed to the southeast, saying to follow it.
After his son left, he closed the door and did not go out again. His cutting off of the net of affection was like this.
In the summer of the seventh year of the Xian-tong era (866), the year of the bing-xu sexagenary cycle, he suddenly went to the houses of his benefactors to say goodbye, saying:
Do good deeds to create blessings. I will be traveling far in the early autumn, so I come to inform you.

In the first month of autumn, on the first day, he washed his hands, burned incense, and contemplated Maitreya Buddha. Then he lay on his right side and called his disciple Xuan Zhang, admonishing him, saying:
The human body is difficult to obtain but easy to lose. Be diligent, have no attachment to things, do nothing, and revolve in the Dharma of no birth and no cessation. Everything is present.
Now that life has limits, I will part from you for a while.
On that day, he passed away without illness. He was over eighty years old.
Xuan Zhang and others, following his last instructions, took his body to the Shi-tuo forest outside Jian-chun Gate, to give it to the birds and beasts.
Three days later, he looked at it again, and the skin and appearance were as if alive, with no one approaching it.
He then covered it with cakes and pastries, and after a night there were traces of foxes and wolves, but they only ate what was covering it, and the body remained solemn as before.
They discussed using foreign methods to cremate it, and collected the remaining ashes to build a white stupa beside the road.
People became even more devoted, and the incense and offerings never ceased.

In the third year of the Xianshun era of the Tang Dynasty, he traveled to famous mountains and finally stayed at Jingshan on the eastern peak of Tianmu.
Monks and laypeople turned to him with faith, and he greatly promoted the teachings of the Dharma.

His disciples who left home included Xianqi of Tiantong Mountain, Xingzhen who was granted the purple robe and lived on the back mountain, and Xingman of Dacisi Mountain. Biography of Zangyi of Suzhou in the Tang Dynasty Biography of Zangyi of Suzhou in the Tang Dynasty Shi Zangyi, with the secular surname Cheng, was from Xin'an, Quzhou.
From a young age, he had a bright and cheerful spirit and a majestic appearance.

During the Yuanhe period, he told his relatives that he wanted to leave home to become a monk. His determination could not be stopped. He went straight to Yuefu on Mount Heng in Changsha and offered himself to Vinaya Master Lingzhi, requesting to be ordained.
Master Lingzhi observed that his strong aspiration was not common, so he accepted him.

After he had shaved his head and donned the Dharma robes, he went to Vinaya Master Zhizong at Kaiyuan Temple in Wuling to receive the complete precepts of discipline, during the third year of the Changqing era.
He then listened to the Vinaya teachings and thoroughly studied the chapters and precepts. He said to his fellow students:
The teachings are vast and extensive, but there is a general approach.
The most urgent matter in the general approach is not to go beyond abandoning the raft.
He then traveled to various Chan schools. He met a senior disciple under Master Masu who was residing at Longya Mountain. Knowing that Zangyi was a Dharma vessel, he told him one day:
The aggregates and elements are not real, and the Buddha's birth is not my own.
What should be the name of your true root?
From whom did you obtain it?
Zhizhao understood with a single word, and a thousand tracks return to the same source.
Longya said:
My Dharma eye is no longer covered.
Having attained what he sought, he greatly gained peace and quiet, and returned to Keshan, probably to avoid the search during the Huichang era.
In the sixth year of the Dazhong era, Prefect Cui Shoushou respected him and built a separate Chan hall for him at Longxing Temple in the prefecture, inviting him to reside there.
After several years, he went north to Jiaxing. Devout Buddhists took refuge in him and asked him to stay at Zhide Monastery.
He then went to Suzhou. At that time, Cui Jun, the prefect of this prefecture, had heard of Zhizhao's name for a long time and invited him to reside at Nanchan Monastery.
In the eighth year of the Xianshun era, Zhexi Prefect Zhou Bao ordered him to reside at Zhaoyin Temple.
That autumn, he returned to Jiaxing. Devout Buddhist layman Lu Jing offered his villa and built the present Yong'an Monastery.

The posthumous title of the Great Master Pu Hui was bestowed by imperial decree, and the stupa was called Faxiang.
Next, Shi Hongcui of Jing Mountain Temple in Yuhang, with the secular surname Wu, was a person from Wuxing.
At the age of 19, he took refuge with the Great Master Wushang at Kaishan Temple, left home and shaved his head, diligently engaged in Buddhist affairs, and never neglected his duties.

At twenty-two, he was sent to Huishan Temple on Mount Song to receive the complete precepts of a fully ordained monk, and was told to recite the precepts for a week. After finishing, he studied the Vinaya.
He then traveled to lecture on the sutras, thinking that being a monk had outstanding work to do, but returned to pay respects to his original teacher, who said:
In the twelve hours of the day, how will you repay the four kinds of kindness and the three kinds of existence?
When Xuan heard this question, he was lost for words. For three days he forgot to eat.
His original teacher then called him back and enlightened him with his original abilities.
In this way, he went back and forth between Mount Yun and Mount He, each time polishing and becoming a skilled craftsman.
Suddenly, during the Huichang period, he was demoted and sent away along with the rest. While the crowd wept and sighed in dismay, Xuan remained calm.
He said:
Great men encounter this difficult situation, isn't it fate?
Why have childish emotions?
At that time, in Changsha, he met the lay believer Luo Yan, who invited him to his home to provide offerings.
It seems that Yicun followed the practice of a white-robed monk, without any mistakes, for two years, like a guest in the household.
In the beginning of the Dazhong era, the law of eradicating the Dharma was abolished, and he then resumed his appearance and returned to his hometown at Xifeng Temple.
In the sixth year of the Xiané€š era, he went to Mount Jiashan to visit his original teacher.
The following year, the Supreme Great Master passed away, and the assembly requested Yicun to succeed to his Dharma position.
At first, there were only a hundred or so monks, but later it filled with thousands.
At that time, the four assemblies lived together in utmost order without transgression.
Emperor Xizong bestowed the temple name Dry-Seal National Protection.
In the third year of the Zhonghe era, he was again bestowed a purple robe.
In the second year of the Jingfu era, the grandfather of the king of the Wu-Yue kingdom, Qian, petitioned to have him appointed and bestowed the title of Dharma-Protector Great Master.
On the twenty-eighth day of the ninth month in the fourth year of the Guanghe era, he took leave of the assembly and passed away.

Qi, the Prefect of Nankang, painted his portrait, and King Wusui wrote a true praise for him. His Dharma disciples were Jingshi of Qixian Temple on Mount Lu, Yizhi of Linchuan, and Lingda of Gongchen Temple.
Lingda greatly spread the Way and teachings in the two Zhejiang regions, and was posthumously titled the Great Master Guisi.
At first, Yicun had the foresight of a sage.
When King Wusui was living at home on Shijian Mountain, and when he went to serve in the army, Yicun saw him once and shook hands with him, and said to him with his attendants screened:
Take good care of yourself.
In the future, you will attain the highest rank and will be the lord of the Buddha Dharma.

Later, he accumulated military merits, became the governor of Hangzhou, and therefore petitioned for Yicun's title of master. Whenever he saw Yicun, he would bow and kneel, and his donations were abundant, unlike the usual number.
When Yicun passed away, he observed the mourning rites, thinking of the words from when he was humble.

The Biography of Daoying of Mount Yunju in Hongzhou during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Daoying of Mount Yunju in Hongzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Daoying, whose surname was Wang, was from Yutian in Jimen.
Born with a special disposition, his spiritual appearance was radiant.
In his childhood, he received the qi of Kongtong.
With a mind to transcend the mundane from an early age, he vied to leave the burning house of home;
Wiping his eyes, he sought a teacher, and thus became the disciple of a goldsmith.
The teacher taught him the scriptures and methods, and he recited them through and sought more.
At the age of twenty-five, he finally received the full precepts at Yan Shou Temple in Fan Yang.
He was then ordered to study the Å›rÄvaka precepts, to which Ying sighed and said:
Can a great man be bound by shackles?
Thus, he put on patched robes, shook his staff, and gathered at Cui Wei Mountain to inquire about the Way for three years.
While staying there, he suddenly saw two messengers with quite unusual hats and robes, who urged Ying to say:
Why not go south to visit knowledgeable teachers?
Before long, a monk from Jiujiang arrived and highly praised Chan Master Dong's essential teachings.
Ying was moved by the spiritual mechanism and thus went straight to him.
In this way, the teachings of Dongshan were passed down and received, and he was able to understand them.
He once asked:
I have heard that Chan Master Siming went to the country of Japan to be the king. Is this true or false?
He replied:
If it were Master Si, he would not even become a Buddha, let alone a king.
From then on, Dongshan approved of him.
He first resided at Sanfeng, and later went to Yunju to expound the Dharma.
At that time, during the late Tang dynasty, the Zhong family controlled Hubei and Huguang, and they sincerely believed in him.
Whenever he was invited to enter the prefecture, they would first purify the Ganzi Hall to receive him.
He then reported it to Emperor Zhaozong, who bestowed on him a set of purple robes and a master's title, but he did not pay any attention to it.
The disciples he transformed, whether in the cold or hot seasons, numbered no less than a thousand.
The ox-head incense trees surrounding him were all sandalwood, and the golden-winged bird king soaring above him was not equal to a sparrow;
Offerings from all directions and followers from a thousand miles away.
For example, the military governor of Jingnan, Cheng Rui, sent him donations worth over a million.
In the first year of Tianfu (885), in the autumn of the Xinyou year, he fell ill and passed away on the third day of the first month of the following year.
The Prince of Nanping in Yuzhang, Zhong Shi, provided for his funeral.

At that time, the Chan monks from various paths, each according to the customs of their native lands, set up flower trees, canopies, and powdered food offerings along the way to the funeral procession, calling it zhuji.
The grand scale of the funeral rites was unprecedented.
Ying was able to ordain people for thirty years, and his legacy can be known.
Shi Youyuan, a monk of Lianyun Temple in Jin'an, Tang Dynasty. His secular surname was Feng, and he was from Zizhong in Dongchuan.
At a young age, he went to Fuhua Temple in Chengdu and served Dinglan, a great man, who was the teacher of Emperor Xuanzong.
He followed him in and out, often staying in the inner palace.
Once summoned, the Emperor wrote on the back of his robe with a brush, saying:
This young boy has a karmic connection with me. From then on, he was summoned by his given name.
In the ninth year of the Dazhong era, he encountered Bai Gong Minzhong, who was sent to garrison Yizhou. He opened a precepts platform and fully received the precepts at Jingzhong Temple.
He then studied sutras and vinaya in the capital for five years.
Later, wearing coarse cloth and carrying an ink edict in his hand, he traveled all over the country.
He visited Xiaoma Shanzhao, and there was no Chan patriarch in the same generation in the monasteries who he did not pay respects to.
He then stayed at Huashan in Chuzhou, and when he traveled south to Wuyi Mountain, Li Hui, the chief administrator, built a Chan hall for him.
In the third year of the Ganyuan era, he arrived at Longquan Dasaishan in Jinyun and established an institute.
He then memorialized the Ministry of Sacrifices to give it a plaque, named Long'an.
The emperor decreed that seven monks be ordained to reside there for eighteen years.
He peacefully moved and stayed at Lianyun Temple.
Lu Yao, the prefect, with a sincere mind of trust, invited him to the separate courtyard of Kaiyuan Temple in the prefecture and provided him with the four necessities.

On the eighth day of the fourth month in the Dingmao year of Tianyou, he showed signs of illness and passed away on the first day of the sixth month at the prefectural office, at the age of 73 and 52 years as a monk.
In his last will, he entrusted Yang Xi, the director of the Bureau of Military Affairs, with the funeral arrangements, to cremate him in the southern garden of the temple.
After the fire was extinguished, hundreds of scattered sarira were collected.
Later, 49 sarira grains and a jar of remaining bones were collected and buried in a stone pagoda.
In the second year of Kaiyun in the Jin dynasty, the monk Wentai composed a stele inscription for the pagoda.

The Biography of Yicun of Xuefeng Guangfu Temple in Fuzhou during the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Yicun of Xuefeng Guangfu Temple in Fuzhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Yicun was born in the second year of Longxing, the 31st year of the sexagenary cycle, in the Zeng family of Nan'an County, Quanzhou.
From his grandfather down, they all befriended monks and were close to the Buddha, pure and reverent in their vows.
While alive, his nose recoiled from the smell of meat.
In the arms of his wet nurse, he would sometimes hear the sound of a bell or see an image of a monk, and his face would always move. For this reason, his parents gave him special love.
At the age of nine, he requested to leave home, but his parents angrily did not agree.
At the age of twelve, he accompanied his uncle to Putian Yujian Temple. There was a Vinaya Master named Qing Xuan, who upheld the precepts with high integrity.
He immediately bowed to him and said:
He is my teacher.
Thus, he stayed on as a novice attendant.
At the age of seventeen, he shaved his head.
He came to pay respects to Master Heng Zhao of Furong Mountain, who saw him as extraordinary and thus stayed with him.
When Emperor Xuanzong revived Buddhism, his teachings were like a withered tree coming back to life, and his body was like a withered flower blooming again.

He traveled north to Wu, Chu, Liang, Song, Yan, and Qin, and received full ordination at Baochao Temple in Youzhou. After completing his studies, he visited famous mountains and knocked on the doors of various Chan masters, standing out like a solitary peak, drifting like clouds, flying like birds.
He then went to Wuling and met Deshan on one side, and stopped at Zhenzhong.
His disciples, numbering in the hundreds, all did not understand.
Deshan said:
This has no steps, I have attained it.
In the ninth year of the Xian Tong era, he returned to the old mountain of Furong.
In that year, Chan Master Yuan Zhi also left Mt. He and led his disciples to Mt. Yi, the place where King Zhen Jun ascended.
His disciples, who had already succeeded Deshan, came in groups and tried to enter, but were stopped for a long time.
There was a monk named Xing Shi, who first discussed with the gatekeeper, saying:
Our way is vast, surrounded by the Dharma gate, one cannot rush into it. The place should be as majestic as a golden brocade.
Two hundred li west of the prefecture, there is a mountain, surrounded by four counties, towering ten thousand feet, supporting the round and green, with mounds looking at the multitude of blues.
Strange rocks and ancient pine trees, tortoises and cranes hibernating, spiritual springs and deep valleys, dragons and thunder hidden and seen.
On the peak of the mountain, it snows before winter and is cold in the middle of summer.
All the trees have separate hanging vines, which are bushy and serve as their clothes, intertwined without revealing their shapes, with strange forms and unusual scenery, indescribable.
Even Huchong and Wuyi cannot surpass it.
It is indeed the spiritual beauty of Minyue, and the ancient immortals have not yet lived here. It truly awaits me.
I pray to go with you.
In the seventh month of autumn, we climbed through the clouds and stepped on the moss, ascended the perilous path and climbed to the secluded place, and were about to reach it. Zhuan said:
This is truly my dwelling place.
That evening, the mountain spirit indeed manifested its spiritual power. The next day, the cliffs and valleys were refreshing, and the mist and clouds were flying.
After the Cloud Hermitage was established, the moon-shaped roof was soon completed. From this, he turned the Dharma wheel in the unconditioned and established the empty gate on the ground.
He requested to name the mountain Xuefeng,
because of its snowy winters and cold summers, taking the meaning of Vulture Peak and Monkey River. This was in the gengyin year.

By the time of the yimao year, he was known for both the mountain and the Way, and the mountain was known for him. Buddhist monks from all over the world, regardless of China or foreign countries, flocked to him as if summoned.

During the Ganyou era, the governor of the region, Jingzhao Wei, and the Minister of Works, Yingchuan Chen, often thirsted for the finest nectar but were unable to drink it. They sent messengers to earnestly request it, and Zuo entered the prefecture to fulfill the people's wishes.

At that time, there were officials who reported to the capital, speaking of his Way and his peers who had left worldly affairs to understand emptiness, requesting them to shed their worldly affairs and come to leave their shoes behind.
Emperor Xizong heard of this, and the Hanlin Academy scholars inquired about him from the Min person Chen Yanxiao, and obtained his true account.
Therefore, he bestowed the title of True Enlightenment Great Master and also gave him a purple robe to be presented by Chen Yanxiao.
He treated receiving as if he were not receiving, and wearing as if he were not wearing.
In the summer of the year Xinhai, he suddenly took up his staff and shoes.
His disciples asked him but he did not reply. Yun followed him, floating east to Danqiu and Siming.
The following year, when Wang Shizhong first controlled Minyue, he washed his troops in Fayu and paid homage in Chanlin. The way of Fu Cun was always facing east, with his hands cupped in respect.
Two years later, he returned to Min from Wu and was greatly honored and treated as an anomaly.
When the king of Min, Wang Shi, vowed to nurture the people, he especially revered his way. Whenever building temples and constructing pagodas for monks, he would always consult him.
He expanded the buildings, set up images, and cast bells to adorn the mountain, and generously gave to fill the assembly.
At that time, he would welcome and lodge them in the eastern and western mansions of the prefecture.
Whenever he was about to set up oil lamps and listen to the Dharma discussions, he would never fail to spend time on it.
In just over a decade, diligently and earnestly, those who were diligent and sincere, followed him to leave traces in the Dana;
Those who were leisurely in fishing and hunting, may have put down their minds towards scales and feathers.
In the spring of the year of Wuchen, in the third month, he showed signs of illness. The King of Min ran to get a doctor. When the doctor arrived, he gave him some pills. Cun said:
I am not sick. I cannot deceive you with my skill.
He resolutely did not take them.
Later, he wrote a verse to leave for his Dharma heirs, and wrote a letter to bid farewell to the royal court.
On the second day of the fifth month of summer, birds and beasts cried sadly, and the clouds and trees were sorrowful.
At the eighteenth watch of that night, he entered nirvana. His secular age was eighty-seven, and his years as a monk were fifty-nine.
On the fifteenth day of that month, he was cremated and buried.
On that day, the monks, nuns, and common people of Min rushed to the funeral, and there were no people left in the streets.
The King of Min, Lian, shed tears and said:
The master has abandoned me, how could this be so sudden!
He sent his son to personally perform sacrifices and offerings, and again held a vegetarian feast for the monks.

Zongmi's transformative activities lasted for over forty years. The number of monks from all directions who vied to attend his Dharma seat was innumerable. Even in winter and summer, there were no less than one thousand five hundred disciples surrounding him.
The more they ran, the further they were away. The more they debated, the more confused they became.
Among them, the one who was almost there was Shibei, who led his disciples at Xuansha (now An Guo).ğŸ”½Next was Ke Xiu, who led his disciples at Dongyan in Yuezhou;

They divided the lamps and transformed beings, all receiving imperial praise. They were given purple robes, and Xuansha was given the title of Great Master Jizong.

With swift runners from the four seas coming to study with him.

Tang Dynasty Biography of Yuanan of Suoxi in Langzhou, Tang Dynasty Biography of Yuanan of Suoxi in Langzhou, Shi Yuanan, with the secular surname Tan, was a person from Lingyou in Fengxiang.
At the age of 10, he left home to become a monk under his uncle, Master You, at Huaien Temple in Qizhou.
He thoroughly studied all the sutras and treatises.
He then inquired about the Way from Cuiwei and Linji, and each time he tasted the Dharma flavor, it was like savoring the food from the fragrant vessel.
He refined and simplified, roaming freely as he pleased.
Hearing that Jiashan had great virtue and fame, he went to Lizhou to ask questions, further increasing his clarity and purity.
Later, he opened up Lepo Mountain and then lived at Su Creek. His answers to questions often used elegant and beautiful phrases, which were passed down throughout the four seas.
In the first year of Guanghua of Emperor Zhaozong's reign (æˆŠåˆ), the twelfth month, he passed away at the age of 65, with 46 years as a monk.

Tang Dynasty, Biography of Hengtong of Xuetou Temple in Mingzhou, Tang Dynasty, Biography of Hengtong of Xuetou Temple in Mingzhou, Zhaoxian Cen Shi Shi Hengtong, secular surname Li, from Pingen, Xingzhou.
His family had passed down the scholar-official class for generations. He knew how to study from a young age.
Even though Su Qin became prominent, he still cherished his two-acre field;
Yuan Liang was aloof, not envying the salary of five dou.
Even if one roams freely, reaching the heavens and trampling the earth, dragging purple and wearing gold, the fleeting glamor of a moment, how can it benefit future lives?
When his parents passed away, at the age of thirteen, he secretly entered Que Mountain to seek the Way and rely on a teacher.

After leaving the ancestral tombs, he only studied Buddhist scriptures, diligently repenting and reciting, earnestly serving as an attendant, not slackening from beginning to end, and was granted permission to shave his head.
At the age of twenty, he received the full precepts at Kaiyuan Temple in his home prefecture.
Later, he went to Caifu Temple in Chang'an to study sutras and vinaya.
For seven or eight years, he thoroughly studied the Buddhist canon and said:
When Dharma Master Zhi Yao came to the Liang Dynasty, he again clarified what matters?
Therefore, he took leave of the northern capital and went directly to the south, where he met with Chan Master Cen of Zhaoxian.
The Chan Master asked:
Where are you from?
He said:
I am from Xingzhou.
Zhaoxian said:
I say you didn't come from there.
Tong said:
Do you still live here, Master?
Thus, all that was stuck was released, and all doubts were resolved.
Later, he pointed to Dongshan and Shishuang, and they all went to study with them.
After Zhaoxian passed away, Tong served him with the etiquette of a disciple.

At the end of the Xian Tong era, he traveled to Xuancheng. The Minister of Works, Cui Yin, who had long revered Chan Buddhism, welcomed and revered him. When he saw Tong's extraordinary appearance and demeanor, and heard their mutual questions and answers, Cui was greatly delighted and impressed.
At Mount Xie Xian, he petitioned to establish a Chan monastery called Ruisheng and invited Tong to reside there.
Monks from all directions gathered without invitation.
When the Prince of Boling planned to recommend Tong for a master's title, Tong firmly declined, and the plan was dropped.
At the end of the Zhong He era and the beginning of the Wen De era, a multitude of bandits rose up.
Tong led his disciples to Si Ming.
In the second year of Daming, the prefect Huang Junshen invited him to stay at Xuefeng, where he flourished.

In the second year of Tianyou, in the seventh month, he showed signs of illness. Nine days later, he personally entered the bathhouse, sat on a rope bed, gathered the assembly, burned incense, earnestly entrusted [the monastery], joined palms, and passed away.
He was seventy-two years old, and had been a monk for fifty-two years.
On the seventh day of the eighth month of that year, his stone pagoda was moved to a place two hundred steps southwest of the monastery.
Some say:
Tong said at the end of his life:
'I am Pang Xun.'
This is not so.
The biography of the eminent monk Wuzhuo does not say this.
If we consider his age, how could Pang Xun have come to escape difficulties at the age of twenty?

The Biography of Shi Huiji of Nanyue in Yuanzhou of the Tang Dynasty. The Biography of Shi Huiji of Nanyue in Yuanzhou of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Huiji, a monk of the Tang dynasty, was from the Ye clan of Xingchang in Shaozhou.
At the age of fifteen, he earnestly requested to leave home, but his parents did not agree.
At seventeen, he again asked his parents, who were still undecided.
That night, two beams of white light came from Caoxi and went straight to his house.
At that time, his parents realized that this was moved by their son's sincerity.
Zhizhao then cut off the ring finger and little finger of his left hand, knelt on the steps of the hall and said:
I thank you for your hard work like this!
His parents knew that he could not be kept, so they let him go and he shaved his head under Chan Master Tong of Nanhu Temple.
At the age of eighteen, he was still a novice.
He prepared his travel gear and went to seek out teachers.
He first saw Danyuan for several years and gained something good.
Later, he met Chan Master Dayu and was inspired by him.
He stayed there for fourteen or fifteen years and his foot became crippled, so he was then called the Cripple Who Drives Crows.
Whenever he discussed [the Dharma], he often showed them [the crippled foot].
At that time, Wei Zhou requested a gÄthÄ from Jizhao, so he took paper and drew a circular shape, with a note below the circle saying:
If you think about it and know it, you fall into the second place.
If you say you know it without thinking, you fall into the third place.
He then sealed it and presented it.
Since then, he has used various postures to show his students, calling it the gate of Nanyue.
The number of disciples who followed him and attained the Way is innumerable.
There are often those with spiritual abilities, who come and go suddenly, and people cannot fathom them.
Later, the emperor posthumously bestowed the title of Great Master on him, named Zhi Tong, and his stupa was called Miaoguang.

Shi Huigong, with the secular surname of Lu, was from Min in Fuzhou.
His family had a tradition of Confucianism and did not associate with non-related people.
When his mother first became pregnant, she dreamed that her dwelling place rose up and floated above the stupa, reaching up to the heavens.
When Gong was born, he was upright and intelligent.
At the age of seventeen, he was selected as a jinshi, and his fame followed the carriage.

He was about to arrive at the capital, but he took a detour to visit Fengri Temple on Zhongnan Mountain. When he saw the remains of the patriarchs, he suddenly became free from the worldly net. He then sought to leave the household life.
He took on the duties of a monk and experienced many hardships.
At the age of twenty-two, he happened to be at the newly established An Guo Temple, where he received full ordination.
He then traveled around, encountering dangers and hardships, but without any discolored expression.
Once he was bitten by a black snake on the finger, but he did not seek medical treatment, and the poison naturally subsided.
He saw a mountain spirit occupying the mountain, and admonished it about sin and blessings, so the demon quickly stopped.
He went to De Shan in Wu Ling and visited Chan Master Xuan Jian, understanding his teachings like a flying wind, and from then on their paths merged.
He then hung his staff and offered the courtesy of a disciple.
After Master Jian passed away, he traveled to Yu Shan.
When he arrived in Xinzhou, the prefect built Xichan Temple for him and paid homage to him. His disciples numbered in the hundreds.
After staying for more than a year, he found the city too noisy and returned to Changxi Maguan Mountain in Fuzhou.

From Maguan, he went to Fuyang Mountain in Quanzhou. Wherever he went, donors gathered, and his disciples collected alms. Meditation halls were built, and laypeople and monastics revered him in this way.
In the third year of Jingfu, he traveled to Tiantai with his disciples. The prefect of the state, Jingzhao Du Xiong, asked him to stay.
Du then built Rulong Temple on Ziniang Mountain, inviting him to lecture on the Dharma to enlighten the deluded.
Monks and laypeople gathered like clouds, and mountains of incense and flowers accumulated.
In the third year of Tianyou, the wu hour of the twelfth month, he ordered the bell to be rung, looked at those around him, and said briefly, Go.
He sat in full lotus posture, closed his eyes, and passed away in a dignified manner. He was 84 years old, and had been a monk for 62 years.

He expounded the perfect and sudden teachings, and was the foremost in morality and virtue. After his death, his name was not changed, and his stupa had no inscription, which shows that floating fame is a shackle.

His disciples and senior students carried on his work, planting pine trees and carrying earth to vigorously build the stupa and temple, which is called the unbreakable cause and condition of Dharma emptiness.
Since there are such causes and conditions, how can filial piety harm the Way?
Tang Dynasty Monk Wenxi of Longquan Temple in Hangzhou, Tang Dynasty Monk Wenxi of Longquan Temple in Hangzhou, Monk Wenxi, whose surname was Zhu, was from Yu'er in Jiahe.
When his mother was pregnant, she dreamed of swallowing three peaches. When he was born, he did not eat meat or pungent things.
At the age of seven, he went to Changle Temple in his native county to become a monk under Monk Qing Guo, who was from Weiyang.
He was made to recite sutras and repentance texts totaling ten scrolls, and then he was allowed to shave his head and put on monastic robes.

He went to Kaiyuan Temple in Yuezhou to study the Lotus Sutra and collect the Tiantai commentaries, and immediately expounded them, which was his ability to lecture on the sutra even while dividing himself to save ants.
In the second year of Kaihuang, he arrived in Zhaozhou, received full ordination, and studied the Four-Part Vinaya.
During the Huichang persecution, he changed into lay clothes, but his mind of secrecy remained unchanged.
When the government allowed the reordination of monks in the early years of the Dazhong era, he lectured at Qifeng Temple in Yan.
Later, he went to pay respects to Chan Master Xingkong of Dacishan, who instructed him:
Why don't you learn from Sudhana and visit teachers everywhere?
In the jiawu year of the Xianqing era, he arrived at Guanyin Temple in Yuzhang and saw Nanyue, who was delighted and entrusted his mind to him.
Nanyue ordered him to manage the temple's affairs.
One day, a monk with an unusual appearance came to request food for the congregation. Xi reduced his own food to give to him.
Nanyue knew in advance and asked:
Did you provide food and service for the monks who came to this place?
He replied:
I stopped my own share and gave it to them.
He said:
You have gained great benefits.
In the seventh year, he returned to Zhejiang and stayed at Mount Qianqing, building a hut to live in.
In the tenth year, Liu Yanhe and Ma Zheng of Yuhang invited him to stay at the ancient city temple of Longquan, where he stayed for eleven years.
In the Kangan year (687), the bandits plundered the land to Yuhang. Xi avoided the chaos and stayed at Yubu Pavilion in Huzhou. Du Ruixiu, the prefect, invited him to stay at Renwang Temple.
In the third year of Guangqi, the Wu-Zhuang King Qian Shi first governed Hangzhou Prefecture and sent a letter inviting him to stay at the old office of Longquan, which is now Ciguang Temple.
In the first year of Dachuang, the military commissioner of Weishengjun, Dong Chang, and the Wu-Zhuang King issued a joint recommendation, and he was granted two purple robes.
In the fourth year of Qianning, he was granted the title of master, Wuzhuo.

In the third year of Guanghe, he fell ill and sat in full lotus posture on the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month, passing away in the prefectural office in the state, at the age of eighty, with sixty years as a monk.
At the time of his death, a white light appeared above the room, and the bamboo trees turned white.
On the twenty-second day of the eleventh month, his pagoda was moved to the western slope of Lingyin Mountain.
Xi was of ancient and simple appearance, with a strong and thin build. He was a true teacher of Chan with the virtue of precepts.
At first, Xi lived in Yanshui.
In the summer of the first year of Guangming, locusts flew in the sky and ate the seedlings in the fields when they landed.
